title: MG and Sleep

content: Myasthenia gravis (MG) weakens your muscles, especially upon exertion. Side effects, other diseases, and additional health conditions can happen after you’re diagnosed.
One of these problems is how it can impact your sleep.
Many people with MG have insomnia, daytime sleepiness, fatigue, and sleep-disordered breathing. These problems can stem from the disease itself, its treatment, or other related factors.

For instance, MG can cause respiratory muscle weakness, leading to sleep apnea and other breathing problems while you sleep. And some medications used to manage MG, like corticosteroids, can contribute to insomnia.

So imagine this: Some of the most used medications for MG are steroids. Taking them is usually long term, or at least a year. The most crucial year is the year of your diagnosis; especially for those who have an MG crisis. Like I did.
One of the most known side effects of steroids is insomnia. Anxiety, depression, and worries about the disease can also negatively impact your sleep.

content: So in a way, we’re stuck in a dilemma. We need to take these meds to survive, but they reduce our quality of life.
So what can we do, as MGers, when facing such a conflict?
Here are tips that helped me with sleep-related problems:
bullets: Your breathing muscles may get weaker. If this happens, or you’re having difficulty breathing, immediately consult with your doctor. Depending on the situation, they might increase your medications, start new ones, or suggest another type of treatment.
I found it helpful to sleep in a higher position that keeps my neck and back high. I even researched medical pillows, and added  them to my sleep routine. They helped raise my back as well.
You may need CPAP to make your breathing more regulated. Talk to your doctor to find the best solution for your specific sleep problems.

Take naps. I can’t recommend this enough. Naps help me during the day, especially when fatigue and sleepiness get the best of me. Your muscles retrieve some of their energy when you give them continuous breaks throughout the day.

Consult with a sleep specialist: It's crucial to discuss sleep problems with them. Talk about any side effects you’re having. Most of those side effects can be treated with medications and improve your quality of life.

Optimize your sleep routine. Establish a regular sleep schedule (easier said than done, I know), create a relaxing bedtime routine, stop caffeine and screen time before bed, and maybe read or meditate to get your body in its most relaxed position.

Finally, take your meds on time! Especially steroids. There’s a reason why we’re required to take them in the morning. If we take them in the afternoon or evening, their side effects last longer. Be consistent with the time you take them every day.

content: I know it can be very frustrating to go through sleeping problems on top of having a difficult chronic illness. But speaking from experience, talking about it helps. Mention it to a friend, talk to your doctor, or tell your therapist.
Experiment with different ideas that may help you sleep better. Most importantly, don’t give up. Remember, you’re a warrior. Whatever happens, it'll always get better.
